qas.question: Why are plants important to human life?
What is the process that converts sunlight to energy?
What is used to rebuild cells?
What vital element is a byproduct of photosynthesis?

context: The study of plants is vital because they underpin almost all animal life on Earth by generating a large proportion of the <a0_0>oxygen and food<a0_0/> that provide humans and other organisms with aerobic respiration with the chemical energy they need to exist. Plants, algae and cyanobacteria are the major groups of organisms that carry out <a1_0>photosynthesis<a1_0/>, a process that uses the energy of sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide into sugars that can be used both as a source of chemical energy and of <a2_0>organic molecules<a2_0/> that are used in the structural components of cells. As a by-product of photosynthesis, plants release <a3_0>oxygen<a3_0/> into the atmosphere, a gas that is required by nearly all living things to carry out cellular respiration. In addition, they are influential in the global carbon and water cycles and plant roots bind and stabilise soils, preventing <a4_0>soil erosion<a4_0/>. Plants are crucial to the future of human society as they provide food, oxygen, medicine, and products for people, as well as creating and preserving soil.
